Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: N-heterocyclic Phosphenium Cation-Containing Pincer Ligands: A Chelating Analogue of the Nitrosyl Ligand and its Non-Innocent Behavior
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemical Catalysis Program, Professor Christine M. Thomas from Brandeis University will focus on developing a new series of redox non-innocent pincer ligands for use in catalysis. She and her students have developed a new class of tridentate pincer ligand incorporating a central N-heterocyclic phosphenium (NHP) unit. While catalytic applications of N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands have been explored extensively, their phosphorus analogues NHPs have not been evaluated in transition metal catalysis, and far less is known about their coordination chemistry. Professor Thomas and coworkers have designed an NHP-containing diphosphine pincer ligand as a method to allow more extensive studies into the transition metal chemistry of NHP ligands. Preliminary results from the Thomas' group strongly support an analogy to nitrosyl ligands, and thus the ability of NHPs to function as redox active ligands to support two-electron transformations is a promising avenue. Professor Thomas and her group will be investigating the coordination chemistry of the new NHP-diphosphine ligands with a wide variety of transition metals and exploring two-electron transformations facilitated by the NHP unit. Computational and electrochemical methods will be used to evaluate the redox-induced transformations in NHP complexes and new NHP-containing multidentate ligands will be investigated. Owing to the importance of multi-electron redox transformations in catalysis, the ultimate goal of the proposed research project is to utilize these analogues of both nitrosyls and NHCs to facilitate catalytic transformations such as C-C or C-X bond forming or breaking reactions, transfer hydrogenation, cross-coupling and other sigma-bond activation processes.

The designed ligands have the potential to support two-electron redox chemistry at metals that are less prone to undergo two-electron transformations. This includes first row transition metals and early transition metals, both of which are cheaper and more naturally abundant than the traditional noble metals used in catalysis such as platinum, palladium and, rhodium. In addition to specific contributions to catalysis, the PI will use the funds to fostering the development of undergraduates interested in chemistry, and to cultivate and interest in science among K-8 students by working closely with local science museums, schools, and after-school clubs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of this project was to develop a better fundamental understanding of catalyst design in an effort to promote the multielectron redox reactions involved in many industrial catalytic cycles using economical and naturally abundant first row transition metals. These so-called “base metals”, including Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu, are often limited in their catalytic applications as a result of their reluctance to undergo multi-electron redox changes.  Careful control of the coordination environment of these metals and the incorporation of coordinated functional groups that can play an active role in catalytic transformations have proven to be effective strategies for the design of base metal catalysts. 

This project specifically focused on a metal-bound functionality, an N-heterocyclic phosphenium cation, and its ability to undergo redox reactions and/or bind substrates upon coordination to a metal (Figure 1).  In order to enforce metal coordination, two different multidentate ligands were developed involving a N-heterocyclic phosphenium cation and either one or two phosphine donors that could also bind to the metal.  A series of metal complexes including those of Pd, Pt, Ni, Cu, and Co were synthesized and their properties and reactivity were explored in an effort to better understand the interplay between the metal and the ligand in a variety of redox processes and stoichiometric bond activation reactions (see, for example Figures 2 and 3). The NSF funded project resulted in 10 peer-reviewed publications detailing our extensive studies into the coordination chemistry and reactivity of N-heterocyclic phosphenium-containing ligands and their two-electron reduced N-heterocyclic phosphido analogues.

In terms of broader impacts, this project also contributed to the training of 5 Ph.D. students, 2 M.S. students, and 5 undergraduate researchers.   In addition, a high school student and a high school teacher were provided with summer research experiences in the PI’s laboratory.  The PI and her research group also worked with the Discovery Museums in Acton, MA to design and implement a mock-glovebox “Reaction Station” to allow even very young children to do messy hands-on chemistry experiments in a controlled environment that is easy to clean up and prevent spills and messes without ruining clothes. A series of activities were designed specifically for implementation in Reaction Station-based activities at the Discovery Science Museum, including hands-on pH measurements using cabbage juice indicators, "explosions" with vinegar and baking soda, and guided inquiry activities to identify "mystery" solids and liquids using what they'd learned about pH and chemical reactions. Exhibit materials were also prepared to show that Reaction Stations simulate the real working environment in the PI's research laboratory and explain to museum visitors why some scientists use gloveboxes in their research.  Inspired by the success of the Reaction Stations with children, the PI also designed more intellectually sophisticated Reaction Station activities for adult audiences.

Modified by: Christine M Thomas

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The focus of this project was to develop a better fundamental understanding of catalyst design in an effort to promote the multielectron redox reactions involved in many industrial catalytic cycles using economical and naturally abundant first row transition metals. These so-called "base metals", including Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu, are often limited in their catalytic applications as a result of their reluctance to undergo multi-electron redox changes. Careful control of the coordination environment of these metals and the incorporation of coordinated functional groups that can play an active role in catalytic transformations have proven to be effective strategies for the design of base metal catalysts. This project specifically focused on a metal-bound functionality, an N-heterocyclic phosphenium cation, and its ability to undergo redox reactions and/or bind substrates upon coordination to a metal (Figure 1). In order to enforce metal coordination, two different multidentate ligands were developed involving a N-heterocyclic phosphenium cation and either one or two phosphine donors that could also bind to the metal. The NSF funded project resulted in 10 peer-reviewed publications detailing our extensive studies into the coordination chemistry and reactivity of N-heterocyclic phosphenium-containing ligands and their two-electron reduced N-heterocyclic phosphido analogues. In terms of broader impacts, this project also contributed to the training of 5 Ph.D. students, 2 M.S. students, and 5 undergraduate researchers. In addition, a high school student and a high school teacher were provided with summer research experiences in the PI?s laboratory. The PI and her research group also worked with the Discovery Museums in Acton, MA to design and implement a mock-glovebox "Reaction Station" to allow even very young children to do messy hands-on chemistry experiments in a controlled environment that is easy to clean up and prevent spills and messes without ruining clothes. Exhibit materials were also prepared to show that Reaction Stations simulate the real working environment in the PI's research laboratory and explain to museum visitors why some scientists use gloveboxes in their research. Inspired by the success of the Reaction Stations with children, the PI also designed more intellectually sophisticated Reaction Station activities for adult audiences.
